sen.j: 上野 信孝（うえの のぶたか、生没年不詳）は、戦国時代の武将。
sen.e: Nobutaka UENO(上野 信孝, dates of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: 原文の「戦国時代 (日本)」をWebに合わせて「戦国時代」に訂正しました。
sen.e: Nobutaka UENO(dates of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記は不必要-他のファイルでも前例がないためです。
sen.e: Nobutaka UENO(year of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに従って、year of birth and death unknownとしました。

sen.e: His original family name was Genji (the Minamoto clan).
His original family name was Genji (the Minamoto clan).
His original family name was Genji (the Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 家系は清和源氏の一家系 河内源氏の流れを汲む足利氏の傍流 上野氏。
sen.e: His family lineage was the Ueno clan, that was a branch of the Ashikaga clan who were descendants of Kawachi-Genji (the Minamoto clan in Kawachi Province), that was one of the family lineages of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).

His family lineage was the Ueno clan, a branch of the Ashikaga clan who were descendants of Kawachi-Genji (the Minamoto clan in Kawachi Province) which was one of the family lineages of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).
sen.cmt: that was は不必要です。, that was →which was
sen.e: His family lineage was the Ueno clan, a branch of the Ashikaga clan who were descendants of Kawachi-Genji (the Minamoto clan in Kawachi Province) which was one of the family lineages of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).
He was a Shogun's retainer in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
He was a Shogun's retainer in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
He was a Shogun's retainer in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
He was a lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province.
sen.cmt: 原文の「鬼邑山城城主」をWebに合わせて「鬼邑山城主」に訂正しました。
sen.e: He was a lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province.
He was a lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province.
His father was Naonaga UENO.
His father was Naonaga UENO.
His father was Naonaga UENO.

sen.j: 子は上野清信、上野頼久。
sen.e: He had children named Kiyonobu UENO and Yorihisa UENO.
He had children named Kiyonobu UENO and Yorihisa UENO.
He had children named Kiyonobu UENO and Yorihisa UENO.

sen.j: 官位は民部大輔従五位下。
sen.e: His official court rank was Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs) of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 原文の「従五位」をWebに合わせて「従五位下」に訂正しました。
sen.e: His official court rank was Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs) of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
His official court rank was Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs) of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: 上野氏は足利氏の支流で足利将軍家の近臣たる家柄。
sen.e: The Ueno clan was a branch of the Ashikaga clan and boasted of the social standing of a family as a trusted vassal of the Ashikaga shogunate family.
The Ueno clan was a branch of the Ashikaga clan and boasted of the social standing of a family as a trusted vassal of the Ashikaga shogunate family.
The Ueno clan was a branch of the Ashikaga clan and boasted of the social standing of a family as a trusted vassal of the Ashikaga shogunate family.

sen.j: 祖先の中には守護を務めた武将もいるが、世襲に至らず京都にあって将軍の側近として幕政を支えていた。
sen.e: Some busho in his ancestors served as Shugo (a provincial military governor), but they did not dare to make their descendants succeed themselves, so the Ueno clan stayed in Kyoto to support the shogunate government as the close advisers to Shogun.

Some busho in his ancestors served as Shugo (a provincial military governor), but they did not make their descendants succeed themselves, so the Ueno clan stayed in Kyoto to support the shogunate government as the close advisers to Shogun.

Some busho in his ancestors served as Shugo (a provincial military governor), but they did not make their descendants succeed themselves, so the Ueno clan stayed in Kyoto to support the shogunate government as the close advisers to Shogun.

sen.j: 信孝は11代将軍足利義稙が従弟 足利義澄に将軍職を追われて、西国に落ち延びると、動向した近臣 上野信孝をして備中国鬼邑山城に封じたのをはじめ、二階堂政行、伊勢貞信もその近隣の諸城に封じて西国における義稙方勢力の形成にあたらせた。
sen.e: When the eleventh Shogun Yoshitane ASHIKAGA was expelled from the shogunate by his cousin Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA and escaped safely to Saigoku (western part of Japan), Nobutaka appointed not only a trusted vassal Nobutaka UENO who had come with Yoshitane to the lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province, but also Masayuki NIKAIDO and Sadanobu ISE to the lords of the other castles at the neighboring spots to make them form the power of the Yoshitane side in Saigoku.
sen.cmt: 原文の「11代征夷大将軍」をWebに合わせて「11代将軍」に訂正しました。原稿の「信孝は・・・動向した近臣 上野信孝をして備中国鬼邑山城に封じたのをはじめ、二階堂政行、伊勢貞信もその近隣の諸城に封じて」の部分の主語は「信孝」であると読み取れるが、「信孝」は一家臣に過ぎないと思われるので、「主述」の関係が不自然だがそのまま訳します。また、「動向」は「同行」だと思われます。
sen.e: When the eleventh Shogun Yoshitane ASHIKAGA was expelled from the shogunate by his cousin Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA and escaped safely to Saigoku (western part of Japan), Nobutaka appointed not only a trusted vassal Nobutaka UENO who had come with Yoshitane to the lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province, but also Masayuki NIKAIDO and Sadanobu ISE to the lords of the other castles at the neighboring spots to make them form the power of the Yoshitane side in Saigoku.

When the eleventh Shogun Yoshitane ASHIKAGA was expelled from the shogunate by his cousin Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA and escaped safely to Saigoku (western part of Japan), Nobutaka appointed not only a trusted vassal Nobutaka UENO who had come with Yoshitane to the lord of Kimurayama-jo Castle in Bicchu Province, but also Masayuki NIKAIDO and Sadanobu ISE to the lords of the other castles at the neighboring spots to make them form the power of the Yoshitane side in Saigoku.

sen.j: 永正年間に、信孝は鬼邑山城を一門の上野高直を入れて城主となし、子の上野頼久をして備中松山城主に封じ自らは帰洛し再び室町幕府に近侍した。
sen.e: In the Eisho era (1504 - 1521), Nobutaka made a member of the clan Takanao UENO enter Kimurayama-jo Castle to make him the lord and appointed his son Yorihisa UENO to the lord of Bicchu Matsuyama-jo Castle, and he himself went back to Kyoto and served in the Muromachi bakufu again.
sen.cmt: 原文の「備中松山城 (備中国)」をWebに合わせて「備中松山城主」に訂正しました。
sen.e: In the Eisho era (1504 - 1521), Nobutaka made a member of the clan Takanao UENO enter Kimurayama-jo Castle to make him the lord and appointed his son Yorihisa UENO to the lord of Bicchu Matsuyama-jo Castle, and he himself went back to Kyoto and served in the Muromachi bakufu again.

In the Eisho era (1504 - 1521), Nobutaka made a member of the clan Takanao UENO enter Kimurayama-jo Castle to make him the lord and appointed his son Yorihisa UENO to the lord of Bicchu Matsuyama-jo Castle, and he himself went back to Kyoto and served in the Muromachi bakufu again.
